This girl, who is older, gives us architecture; you look through an arch, which leads into a side street, and, in the foreground, Antony stands on a platform at the head of a flight ot marble steps. Antony's attitude expresses indig nation and scorn. Below, is a crowd of Romans wearing the toga, whose attitudes show various shades of consternation and dismay. Behind, is Antony's servant in uniform, holding his master's horse; and on the platform, in the rear of Antony, lies Caesar, with the royal purple thrown over him. The chief value of the drawing, as a drawing, is that it tells the tale.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA293.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Another girl draws Calpurnia begging Caesar not to go to the Senate. Caesar stands armed and perturbed, while Calpurnia holds his outstretched hand with both of hers as she kneels before him, her face raised in entreaty ; her loose blue night-robe and long golden hair give colour to the picture. This artist is fourteen, and the drawing is better done.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA293.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
Another artist presents Brutus and Portia in the orchard with a 'south-wall' of red brick, espaliers, and two dignified figures which hardly tell their tale.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA293.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
Another child gives us the scene in the forum, Caesar seated in royal purple, Brutus kneeling before him, and Casca standing behind his chair with outstretched hand holding a dagger, saying "Speak,<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0076.xml#para.329.1.0.box.227.241.997.82.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> hands, for me," while Caesar says, "Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?"</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378673971599 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294"></span></a>
<div id="content-0076.xml#block.329.1.0.box.226.241.1002.1673.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
Again, we get Lucius playing to Brutus in the tent. Brutus, armed cap-a-pie, seated on a stool, is vainly trying to read, while Lucius, a pretty figure, seated before him, plays the harp. The two sentries, also fully armed, are stretched on the floor sound asleep.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Another, gives us Claudius dressed as a woman at the women's festival—the ladies with remarkable eyes, and each carrying a flaming torch.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
Another pictures, with great spirit, Caesar reading his history to the conquered Gauls, who stand in rows on the hillside listening to the great man with exemplary patience.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
In these original illustrations (several of them by older children than those we have in view here), we get an example of the various images that present themselves to the minds of children during the reading of a great work; and a single such glimpse into a child's mind convinces us of the importance of sustaining that mind upon strong meat. Imagination does not stir at the suggestion of the feeble, muchdiluted stuff that is too often put into children's hands.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
'Playing at' History.—Children have other ways of expressing the conceptions that fill them when they are duly fed. They play at their history lessons, dress up, make tableaux, act scenes; or they have a stage, and their dolls act, while they paint the scenery and speak the speeches. There is no end to the modes of expression children find when there is anything in them to express.

<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA294.w.1.6.0"></span></a>
The mistake we make is to suppose that imagination is fed by nature, or that it works on the insipid diet of children's story-books. Let a child have the<span id="content-0076.xml#GBS.PA295.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0076.xml#para.330.1.0.box.46.195.1003.242.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> meat he requires in his history readings, and in the literature which naturally gathers round this history, and imagination will bestir itself without any help of ours; the child will live out in detail a thousand scenes of which he only gets the merest hint.</span>

</div>

</div>

<div id="content-0077.xml#block.330.2.0.box.48.503.1010.1344.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA295.w.2.0.0"></span></a>
XIX.—GRAMMAR

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA295.w.2.1.0"></span></a>
Grammar a Difficult Study.—<span style="font-style:italic;">Of </span><span style="font-style:italic;">grammar, </span>Latin and English, I shall say very little here. In the first place, grammar, being a study of <span style="font-style:italic;">words </span>and not of <span style="font-style:italic;">things, </span>is by no means attractive to the child, nor should he be hurried into it . English grammar, again, depending as it does on the position and logical connection of words, is peculiarly hard for him to grasp. In this respect the Latin grammar is easier; a change in the form, the <span style="font-style:italic;">shape </span>of the word, to denote case, is what a child can see with his bodily eye, and therefore is plainer to him than the abstract ideas of nominative and objective case as we have them in English. Therefore, if he learns no more at this early stage than the declensions and a verb or two, it is well he should learn thus much, if only to help him to see what English grammar would be at when it speaks of a change in case or mood, yet shows no change in the form of the word.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA295.w.2.2.0"></span></a>
Latin Grammar.—Of the teaching of Latin grammar, I think I cannot do better than mention a book for beginners that really answers. Children of eight and nine take to this <span style="font-style:italic;">First </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Latin </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Course </span>(Scott and Jones)^1^ very kindly, and it is a great thing to begin a study with pleasure. It is an open question, however, whether it is desirable to begin Latin at so early an age.

</div>

<div id="content-0077.xml#block.330.3.0.box.427.1849.254.32.q.60" class="gtxt_footnote">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA295.w.3.0.0"></span></a>
^1^ See Appendix A.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378676861413 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296"></span></a>
<div id="content-0077.xml#block.331.1.0.box.190.210.1006.1678.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
English Grammar a Logical Study.—Because English grammar is a logical study, and deals with <span style="font-style:italic;">sentences </span>and the positions that words occupy in them, rather than with <span style="font-style:italic;">words, </span>and what they are in their own right, it is better that the child should begin with the <span style="font-style:italic;">sentence, </span>and not with the parts of speech; that is, that he should learn a little of what is called <span style="font-style:italic;">analysis </span>of sentences before he learns to parse; should learn to divide simple sentences into the thing we speak of, and what we say about it— 'The cat—sits on the hearth'—before he is lost in the fog of person, mood, and part of speech.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
'"So then I took up the next book. It was about grammar. It said extraordinary things about nouns and verbs and particles and pronouns, and past participles and objective cases and subjunctive moods. 'What are all these things?' asked the King. 'I don't know, your Majesty,' and the Queen did not know, but she said it would be very suitable for children to learn. It would keep them quiet,'"^1^

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
It is so important that children should not be puzzled as were this bewildered King and Queen, that I add a couple of introductory grammar lessons; as a single example is often more useful than many precepts.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-variant:small-caps;">Lesson </span>I

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
Words put together so as to make sense form what is called a sentence.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
'Barley oats chair really good and cherry' is not a sentence, because it makes no(n)sense.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.6.0"></span></a>
'Tom has said his lesson' is a sentence.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.7.0"></span></a>
It is a sentence because it tells us something about Tom.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA296.w.1.8.0"></span></a>
^1^ <span style="font-style:italic;">Palace </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Tales, </span>II. Fielding.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378678154495 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297"></span></a>
<div id="content-0077.xml#block.332.1.0.box.46.194.997.1528.q.60" class="gtxt_body" style="margin-bottom: 1.5em;">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
Every sentence speaks of someone or of something, and tells us something about that of which it speaks. So a sentence has two parts:

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
\(1) The thing we speak of;

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
\(2) What we say about it.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
In our sentence, we speak of' Tom.'

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
We say about him that he 'has learned his lesson.'

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
The thing we speak of is often called the SUBJECT, which just means that which we talk about.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.6.0"></span></a>
People sometimes say ' the <span style="font-style:italic;">subject </span>of conversation was so and so,' which is another way of saying ' the thing we were speaking about was so and so.'

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.7.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-style:italic;">To </span><span style="font-style:italic;">be </span><span style="font-style:italic;">learnt</span>—

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.8.0"></span></a>
Words put together so as to make sense form a sentence.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.9.0"></span></a>
A sentence has two parts: that which we speak of, and what we say about it.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.10.0"></span></a>
That which we speak of is the SUBJECT.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.11.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-style:italic;">Exercises </span><span style="font-style:italic;">on </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Lesson </span><span style="font-style:italic;">I </span>

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.12.0"></span></a>
1\. Put the first part to—

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.13.0"></span></a>
has a long mane.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.14.0"></span></a>
is broken.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.15.0"></span></a>
cannot do his sums.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.16.0"></span></a>
played for an hour; etc., etc.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.17.0"></span></a>
2\. Put the second part to—

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.18.0"></span></a>
That poor boy .

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.1.19.0"></span></a>
My brother Tom •.

</div>

<div id="content-0077.xml#block.332.2.0.box.212.1732.658.137.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.2.0.0"></span></a>
The broken flowerpot

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.2.1.0"></span></a>
Bread and jam .

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA297.w.2.2.0"></span></a>
Brown's tool-basket ;etc., etc.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378679331454 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298"></span></a>
<div id="content-0077.xml#block.333.1.0.box.190.206.1002.1679.q.50" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
3\. Put six different subjects to each half sentence in 1.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
4\. Make six different sentences with each subject in 2.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
5\. Say which part of the sentence is wanting, and supply it in—

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
Has been mended

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
Tom's knife

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
That little dog

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.6.0"></span></a>
Cut his finger

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.7.0"></span></a>
Ate too much fruit

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.8.0"></span></a>
My new book

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.9.0"></span></a>
The snowdrops in our garden, etc., etc.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.10.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-style:italic;">N.B.</span>—Be careful to call the first part of each sentence the <span style="font-style:italic;">subject. </span>

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.11.0"></span></a>
Draw a line under the subject of each sentence in all the exercises.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.12.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-variant:small-caps;">Lesson </span>II

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.13.0"></span></a>
We may make a sentence with only two words—the name of the thing we speak of and what we say about it:—

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.14.0"></span></a>
John writes.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.15.0"></span></a>
Birds sing.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.16.0"></span></a>
Mary sews.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA298.w.1.17.0"></span></a>
We speak about' John.' We say about him that he 'writes.' We speak about ' birds.' We say about them that they ' sing.' These words, <span style="font-style:italic;">writes, </span><span style="font-style:italic;">sing, </span><span style="font-style:italic;">sews, </span>all come out of the same group of words, and the words in that group are<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA299.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0077.xml#para.334.1.0.box.46.194.1000.142.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> the chief words of all, for this reason—we cannot make sense, and therefore cannot make a sentence, without using at least one of them.</span>

</div>

</div>

They are called <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">Verbs, </span>which means <span style="font-style:italic;">words, </span>because they are the chief <span style="font-style:italic;">words </span>of all.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA299.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
A verb always tells one of two things about the\
subject. Either it tells what the subject <span style="font-style:italic;">is, </span>as—\
 I <span style="font-style:italic;">am </span>hungry.\
 The chair <span style="font-style:italic;">is </span>broken.\
 The birds <span style="font-style:italic;">are </span>merry;\
or it tells what the subject does, as—\
 Alice <span style="font-style:italic;">writes. </span>\
 The cat <span style="font-style:italic;">mews. </span>\
 He <span style="font-style:italic;">calls. </span>\
<span style="font-style:italic;"> To </span><span style="font-style:italic;">be </span><span style="font-style:italic;">learnt</span>—\

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA299.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
We cannot make a sentence without a verb.\
<span style="font-style:italic;"> Verb </span>means <span style="font-style:italic;">word. </span>\
 Verbs are the chief words.\
 Verbs show that the subject is something—\
 He is sleepy;\
or does something—\

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA299.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
He runs.

<span id="content-0077.xml#GBS.PA299.w.1.5.0"></span></a>

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA300.w.2.0.0"></span></a>
XX.—FRENCH

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA300.w.2.1.0"></span></a>
French should be acquired as English is, not as a grammar, but as a living speech. To train the ear to distinguish and the lips to produce the French vocables is a valuable part of the education of the senses, and one which can hardly be undertaken too soon. Again, all educated persons should be able to speak<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA301.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0078.xml#para.336.1.0.box.54.238.1002.541.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> French. Sir Lyon Playfair, once speaking at a conference of French masters, lamented feelingly our degeneracy in this respect, and instanced the grammar school of Perth to show that in a Scotch school in the sixteenth century the boys were required to speak <span style="font-style:italic;">Latin </span>during school hours, and <span style="font-style:italic;">French </span>at all other times. There is hardly another civilised nation so dull in acquiring foreign tongues as we English of the present time; but, probably, the fault lies rather in the way we set about the study than in any natural incapacity for languages.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378683270705 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA301"></span></a>
<div id="content-0078.xml#block.336.1.0.box.45.238.1011.1677.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA301.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
As regards French, for instance, our difficulties are twofold—the want of a vocabulary, and a certain awkwardness in producing unfamiliar sounds. It is evident that both these hindrances should be removed in early childhood. The child should never see French words in print until he has learned to say them with as much ease and readiness as if they were English. The desire to give printed combinations of letters the sounds they would bear in English words is the real cause of our national difficulty in pronouncing French. Again, the child's vocabulary should increase steadily, say, at the rate of half a dozen words a day. Think of fifteen hundred words in a year! The child who has that number of words, and knows how to apply them, can speak French. Of course, his teacher will take care that, in giving words, she gives idioms also, and that as he learns new words, they are <span style="font-style:italic;">put </span><span style="font-style:italic;">into </span><span style="font-style:italic;">sentences </span><span style="font-style:italic;">and </span><span style="font-style:italic;">kept </span><span style="font-style:italic;">in </span><span style="font-style:italic;">use </span><span style="font-style:italic;">from </span><span style="font-style:italic;">day </span><span style="font-style:italic;">to </span><span style="font-style:italic;">day. </span>A note-book in which she enters the child's new words and sentences will easily enable the teacher to do this. The young child has no foolish shame about <span style="font-style:italic;">saying </span>French words—he pronounces them as simply as if they were English;<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA302.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0078.xml#para.337.1.0.box.181.243.1000.341.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> but it is very important that he should acquire a pure accent from the first. It is not often advisable that young English children should be put into the hands of a French governess or nurse; but would it not be possible for half a dozen families, say, to engage a French lady, who would give half an hour daily to each family?</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378684838653 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA302"></span></a>
<div id="content-0078.xml#block.337.1.0.box.181.243.1006.1627.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA302.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
M. Gouin's Method.—A serious effort is being made to approach the study of foreign languages rationally and scientifically. I have no hesitation in saying that M. Gouin's work <span style="font-style:italic;">(The </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Art </span><span style="font-style:italic;">of </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Teach</span><span style="font-style:italic;">ing </span><span style="font-style:italic;">and </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Studying </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Languages)</span><span style="font-style:italic;">^1^ </span>is the most important attempt that has yet been made to bring the study of languages within the sphere of practical education. Indeed, the great reform in our methods of teaching modern languages owe their origin to this remarkable work. The initial idea, that we must acquire a new language as a child acquires his mother tongue, is absolutely right, whether the attempt to follow this idea out by analysing a language into a certain number, say fifteen, exhaustive 'series,' be right or not. Again, it is incontestable that the ear, and not the eye, is the physical organ for apprehending a language, just as truly as it is by the mouth, and not the ear, we appropriate food. If M. Gouin's book establish these two points only, it will be a valuable contribution to educational thought. Equally important is his third position, that the verb is the key to the sentence, and more, is the living bridge between thought and act. He maintains, too, that the child thinks in sentences, not in words; that his sentences have a logical sequence; that this sequence is one of time<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA303.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0078.xml#para.338.1.0.box.46.235.1002.1335.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> —the order of the operations in, for example, the growth of a plant, or the grinding of corn in a mill; that, as the child perceives the operations, he has an absolute need to express them; that his ear solicits, his memory cherishes, his tongue reproduces, the words which say the thing he thinks. No doubt M. Gouin's method should be more successful than any other in steeping the student (child or man) in German or French thought. If you are all day long trying to work out a 'series' in French, say, you come to think in French, to 'dream in French,' to <span style="font-style:italic;">speak </span>French. Moreover, one has a delightful sense that at last the way is made clear to us to conduct all teaching in the language under study. You have the 'Art Series' and the 'Bee Series' and the 'River' and the 'Character Series' and the 'Poet Series,' and any series you like. You think the thing out in the order of time and natural sequence; you get the right <span style="font-style:italic;">verbs, </span>nouns, and such epithets as are necessary, follow suit, and in amazingly few sentences, very short sentences too, connected by 'and,' you have said <span style="font-style:italic;">all </span>that is essential to the subject. The whole thing is a constant surprise, like the children's game which unearths the most extraordinary and out-of-the-way thing you can think of by means of a dozen or so questions.</span>

</div>

<div id="content-0078.xml#block.337.2.0.box.551.1887.264.34.q.60" class="gtxt_footnote">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA302.w.2.0.0"></span></a>
^1^ See Appendix A.

</div>

</div>

<div id="content-0078.xml#block.338.1.0.box.46.235.1002.1681.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA303.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
The 'Series.'—Thus, a language learned by M. Gouin's method is ' a liberal education in itself.' One learns how few and simple are, after all, the conceptions of which the human mind is cognisant, and how few and simple, putting mere verbiage aside, are the words necessary to express these.

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA303.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
You really learn to <span style="font-style:italic;">think </span>in the new language,<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0078.xml#para.339.1.0.box.188.229.998.42.q.70" class="gtxt_body"> because you have no more than vague impressions</span>

</div>

</div>

<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304"></span></a>
<div id="content-0078.xml#block.339.1.0.box.188.229.1003.1175.q.60" class="gtxt_body" style="margin-bottom: 1.5em;">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
about these acts or facts in your mother tongue.

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
You order your thoughts in the new language, and, having done so, the words which express these are an inalienable possession.

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.1.3.0"></span></a>

She shuts up the match-box, <span style="font-style:italic;">shuts </span><span style="font-style:italic;">up. </span>

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.1.9.0"></span></a>

Stands up again, <span style="font-style:italic;">stands </span><span style="font-style:italic;">up. </span>

<div id="content-0078.xml#block.339.2.0.box.197.1462.999.436.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.2.0.0"></span></a>
But any attempt to quote gives an uncertain and unsatisfactory idea of this important work.

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.2.1.0"></span></a>
How does the Child learn ?—Whatever may be said of M. Gouin's methods, the steps by which he arrives at them are undoubtedly scientific. He learns from a child:

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA304.w.2.2.0"></span></a>
"Unhappily the child has remained up to the present a hackneyed riddle, which we have never taken sufficient trouble to decipher or examine. ..."

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378689749938 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA305"></span></a>
<div id="content-0078.xml#block.340.1.0.box.45.195.1009.1675.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA305.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
"The little child, which at the age of two years utters nothing but meaningless exclamations, at the age of three finds itself in possession of a complete language. How does it accomplish this? Does this miracle admit of explanation or not? Is it a problem of which there is a possibility of finding the unknown quantity? . . . The organ of language— ask the little child—is not the eye: it is the ear. The eye is made for colours, and not for sounds and words. . . . This tension, continuous and contrary to nature, of the organ of sight, the forced precipitancy of the visual act, produced what it was bound to produce, a disease of the eyesight."

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA305.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
This refers to M. Gouin's herculean labours in the attempt to learn German. He knew everybody's 'Method,' learned the whole dictionary through, and found at the end that he did not know <span style="font-style:italic;">one </span><span style="font-style:italic;">word </span>of German ' as she is spoke.'

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA305.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
He returned to France, after a ten months' absence, and found that his little nephew—whom he had left, a child of two and a half, not yet able to talk—had in the interval done what his uncle had signally failed to do. "'What!' I thought; 'this child and I have been working for the same time, each at a language. He, playing round his mother, running after flowers, butterflies and birds, without weariness, without apparent effort, without even being conscious of his work, is able to say all he thinks, express all he sees, understand all he hears; and when he began his work, his intelligence was yet a futurity, a glimmer, a hope. And I, versed in the sciences, versed in philosophy, armed with a powerful will, gifted with a powerful memory .... have arrived at nothing, or at practically nothing!'"

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378691153718 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA306"></span></a>
<div id="content-0078.xml#block.341.1.0.box.214.222.1005.1679.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA306.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
"The linguistic science of the college has deceived me, has misguided me. The classical method, with its grammar, its dictionary, and its translations, is a delusion." "To surprise Nature's secret, I must watch this child."

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA306.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
M. Gouin watches the child—the work in question is the result of his observations.

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA306.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
The method of teaching may be varied, partly because that recommended by M. Gouin requires a perfect command of the French tongue, and teachers who are diffident find a conversational method founded on book and picture^2^ easier to work and perhaps as effectual—more so, some people think; but, be this as it may, it is to M. Gouin we owe the fundamental idea.

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA306.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
It is satisfactory to find principles, which we have urged continually, enunciated in this most thoughtful work. For example: "If one learns French without being able to read it—as the child does— there will be no longer much greater difficulty in pronouncing it than in pronouncing words in English. 'How about the spelling?' you will ask. The spelling? You would learn it as the young French children learn it, as you yourself have learnt the English spelling, ten times more difficult than the French; and this without letting the study of the spelling spoil your already acquired pronunciation. Besides, the spelling is a thing that can be reformed— the pronunciation hardly at all. We must choose between the two evils." M. Gouin speaks of the possibility of a child's picking up another tongue— even Chinese from a Chinese nurse; and his words remind me of an extraordinary instance of a child's ^1^ See Appendix A.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378692729450 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA307"></span></a>
<div id="content-0078.xml#block.342.0.0.box.46.180.1002.1019.q.60" class="gtxt_body" style="margin-bottom: 1.5em;">

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA307.w.0.0.0"></span></a>
LESSONS AS INSTRUMENTS OF EDUCATION 307

<span id="content-0078.xml#GBS.PA307.w.0.1.0"></span></a>
facility in picking up languages, which once came before me. Having occasion to speak in public of three little children, all aged three, belonging to different families, where one parent was English, the other German, I said that these three children of my acquaintance could each say everything they had to say, express the whole range of their ideas, with equal ease and fluency in the two languages. At the close of the meeting, a gentleman present came forward and endorsed my remarks. He said he had a son whose wife was a German lady, and who was now a missionary in Bagdad. They have a child of three, and their child speaks <span style="font-style:italic;">three </span>languages with perfect fluency—English, German, and Arabic! No doubt the child will forget two of the three, and this is no argument for teaching foreign tongues to babies, but surely it does prove that the acquisition of a foreign tongue need not present insuperable difficulties to any of us.

</div>

</div>

<span id="content-0079.xml"></span>

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA307.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
XXI.—PICTORIAL ART

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA307.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
Study of Pictures.—The art training of children should proceed on two lines. The six-year-old child should begin both to express himself and to appreciate, and his appreciation should be well in advance of his power to express what he sees or imagines. Therefore it is a lamentable thing when the appreciation of children is exercised only upon the coloured lithographs of their picture-books or of the ' Christmas number.' But the reader will say, 'A young child cannot appreciate art; it is only the colour and sentiment of a picture that reach him. A vividly coloured presentation of Bobbie's Birthday, or of<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA308.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0079.xml#para.343.1.0.box.218.251.1007.1177.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> Barbara's Broken Doll, will find its way straight to his "business and bosom."' 'Therefore,' says the reader, 'Nature indicates the sort of art proper for the children!' But, as a matter of fact, the minds of children and of their elders alike accommodate themselves to what is put in their way; and if children appreciate the vulgar and sentimental in art, it is because that is the manner of art to which they become habituated. A little boy of about nine was (with many others) given reproductions of some halfdozen of the pictures of Jean Francois Millet to study during a school term. At the end, the children were asked to describe the one of these pictures which they liked best. Of course they did it, and did it well. This is what the little boy I mentioned makes of it:— "I liked the Sower best. The sower is sowing seeds; the picture is all dark except high up on the righthand side where there is a man ploughing the field. While he is ploughing the field the sower sows. The sower has got a bag in his left hand and is sowing with his right hand. He has wooden clogs on. He is sowing at about six o'clock in the morning. You can see his head better than his legs and body, because it is against the light."</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378694467988 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA308"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.343.1.0.box.215.251.1010.1676.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA308.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
A little girl of seven prefers the 'Angelus,' and says:—" The picture is about people in the fields, a man and a woman. By the woman is a basket with something in it; behind her is a wheelbarrow. They are praying; the man has his hat off in his hand. You can tell that it is evening, because the wheelbarrow and the basket are loaded."

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA308.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Should be Regular.—When children have begun regular lessons (that is, as soon as they are six), this sort of study of pictures should not<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA309.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0079.xml#para.344.1.0.box.46.194.999.184.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> De left to chance, but they should take one artist after another, term by term, and study quietly some half-dozen reproductions of his work in the course of a term.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378696232538 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA309"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.344.1.0.box.45.194.1002.1680.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA309.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
The little memory outlines I have quoted show that something definite remains with a child after his studies; but this is the least of the gains. We cannot measure the influence that one or another artist has upon the child's sense of beauty, upon his power of seeing, as in a picture, the common sights of life; he is enriched more than we know in having really looked at even a single picture. It is a mistake to think that colour is quite necessary to children in their art studies. They find colour in many places, and are content, for the time, with form and feeling in their pictures. By the way, for schoolroom decorations, I know of nothing better than the Fitzroy Pictures,^1^ especially those of the Four Seasons, where you get beauty, both of line and colour, and poetic feeling. I should like, too, to quote Ruskin's counsel that English children should be brought up on Jean Richter's picture-books for children, the <span style="font-style:italic;">Unser </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Vater, </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Sontag} </span>and the rest.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA309.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
I subjoin notes of a lesson on a Picture-talk ^2^ given to children of eight and nine, to show how this sort of lesson may be given.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA309.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-variant:small-caps;">P1cture-talk </span>\
<span style="font-style:italic;"> "Objects </span>\

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA309.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
"1. To continue the series of Landseer's pictures the children are taking in school.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA309.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
"2. To increase their interest in Landseer's works. ^1^ See Appendix A. ^a^ By a student of the House of Education.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378698486251 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.345.1.0.box.194.205.1005.1677.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
"3. To show the importance of his acquaintance with animals.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
"4. To help them to read a picture truly.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
"5. To increase their powers of attention and observation.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">I.</span>—Ask the children if they remember what their last picture-talk was about, and what artist was famous for animal-painting. Tell them Landseer was acquainted with animals when he was quite young: he had dogs for pets, and because he loved them he studied them and their habits—so was able to paint them.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">II.</span>—Give them the picture 'Alexander and Diogenes' to look at, and ask them to find out all they can about it themselves, and to think what idea the artist had in his mind, and what idea or ideas he meant his picture to convey to us.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">III.</span>—After three or four minutes, take the picture away and see what the children have noticed. Then ask them what the different dogs suggest to them: the strength of the mastiff representing Alexander; the dignity and stateliness of the bloodhounds in his rear; the look of the wise counsellor on the face of the setter; the rather contemptuous look of the rough-haired terrier in the tub. Ask the children if they have noticed anything in the picture which shows the time of day: for example, the tools thrown down by the side of the workman's basket suggesting the mid-day meal; and the bright sunshine on the dogs who cast a shadow on the tub shows it must be somewhere about noon.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA310.w.1.6.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">IV.</span>—Let them read the title, and tell any facts they know about Alexander and Diogenes; then tell them Alexander was a great conqueror who lived<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0079.xml#para.346.1.0.box.47.195.998.341.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> B.C. 356-323, famous for the battles he won against Persia, India, and along the coast of the Mediterranean. He was very proud, strong, and boastful. Diogenes was a cynic philosopher. Explain cynic, illustrating by the legend of Alexander and Diogenes; and from it find out which dog represents Alexander and which Diogenes.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378700054909 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.346.1.0.box.46.195.1005.1630.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">V.</span>—Let the children draw the chief lines of the picture, in five minutes, with pencil and paper."

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Original Illustrations.—I have spoken, from time to time, of original illustrations drawn by the children. It may be of use to subjoin notes of a lesson^1^ showing the sort of occasional help a teacher may give in this kind of work; but in a general way it is best to leave children to themselves.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Objects </span>

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-style:italic;">"</span>1. To help the children to make clear mental pictures from description, and to reproduce the same in painting.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
"2. To increase their power of imagination.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.6.0"></span></a>
"3. To help them in their ideas of form and colour.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.7.0"></span></a>
"4. To increase their interest in the story of Beowulf by letting them illustrate a scene from the book they are reading.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.8.0"></span></a>
"5. To bring out their idea of an unknown creature (Grendel).

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.9.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Steps </span>

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.10.0"></span></a>
<span style="font-style:italic;">"Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">I.</span>—To draw from the children what they

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.11.0"></span></a>
know of the poem 'Beowulf,' and of the hero himself.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.1.12.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">II.</span>—To tell them any points they may miss<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0079.xml#para.347.1.0.box.211.225.1000.90.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> in the story, as far as they have read <span style="font-style:italic;">(i.e. </span>to the death of Grendel).</span>

</div>

<div id="content-0079.xml#block.346.2.0.box.258.1846.578.32.q.60" class="gtxt_footnote">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA311.w.2.0.0"></span></a>
^1^ By a student of the House of Education.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378701812215 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.347.1.0.box.211.225.1012.1672.q.50" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">III.</span>—To read the description of the dress at that time, and the account of Grendel's death (including three possible pictures).

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">IV.</span>—To draw from the children what mental pictures they have made—and to re-read the passage.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">V.</span>—To let them produce their mental picture with brush and paint.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312.w.1.4.0"></span></a>
"<span style="font-style:italic;">Step </span><span style="font-style:italic;">VI.</span>—To show them George Harrow's 'original illustration' of Beowulf in <span style="font-style:italic;">Heroes </span><span style="font-style:italic;">of </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Chivalry </span><span style="font-style:italic;">and </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Romance'' </span>

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312.w.1.5.0"></span></a>
Drawing Lessons.—But 'for their actual drawing lessons,' says the reader, 'I suppose you use "blobs " ?'—' blobs,' <span style="font-style:italic;">i.e. </span>splashes of paint made with the flat of the brush, which take an oval form. I think blobs have one use—they give a certain freedom in using colour. Otherwise 'blobs' seem to me a sort of apparatus of art which a child acquires with a good deal of labour, and with which, by proper combinations into flowers, and so on, he can produce effects beyond his legitimate power as an artist, while all the time he can do this without a particle of the feeling for the natural object which is the very soul of art. The power of effective creation by a sort of clever trick maims those delicate feelers of a child's nature by which he apprehends art.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA312.w.1.6.0"></span></a>
"Let the eye" (says Ruskin) " but rest on a rough piece of branch of curious form during a conversation with a friend, rest, however unconsciously, and though the conversation be forgotten, though every circumstance connected with it be as utterly lost to the memory as though it had not been, yet the eye will, through the whole life after, take a certain<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA313.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0079.xml#para.348.1.0.box.52.200.1002.235.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> pleasure in such boughs which it had not before, a pleasure so slight, a trace of feeling so delicate, as to leave us utterly unconscious of its peculiar power, but undestroyable by any reasoning, a part thenceforward of our constitution."</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378703063007 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA313"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.348.1.0.box.52.200.1017.1679.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA313.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
This is what we wish to do for children in teaching them to draw—to cause the eye to rest, not unconsciously, but consciously, on some object of beauty which will leave in their minds an image of delight for all their lives to come. Children of six and seven draw budding twigs of oak and ash, beech and larch,' with such tender fidelity to colour, tone, and gesture, that the crude little drawings are in themselves things of beauty.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA313.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Children have 'Art' in them.—With art, as with so many other things in a child, we must believe that it is there, or we shall never find it. Once again, here is a delicate Ariel whom it is our part to deliver from his bonds. Therefore we set twig or growing flower before a child and let him deal with it as he chooses. He will find his own way to form and colour, and our help may very well be limited at first to such technical matters as the mixing of colours and the like. In order that we may not impede the child's freedom or hinder the deliverance of the art that is in him, we must be careful not to offer any aids in the way of guiding lines, points, and such other crutches; and, also, he should work in the easiest medium, that is, with paint brush or with charcoal, and <span style="font-style:italic;">not </span>with a black-lead pencil. Boxes of cheap colours are to be avoided. Children are worthy of the best, and some half-dozen tubes of really good colours will last a long time, and will satisfy the eye of the little artists.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA313.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
Clay-modelling.—While speaking of the art train<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA314.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0079.xml#para.349.1.0.box.179.211.1009.738.q.60" class="gtxt_body">ing of children, it may be as well to give a word to clay-modelling. Neat little birds'-nests, baskets of eggs, etc., are of no use in the way of art development, and soon cease to be amusing. The chief thing the teacher has to do is to show the child how to prepare his clay so as to expel air-bubbles, and to give him the idea of making a little platform for his work, so that it may from the first have an artistic effect. Then put before him an apple, a banana, a Brazil nut, or the like; let him, not take a lump of clay and squeeze it into shape, but build up the shape he desires morsel by morsel. His own artistic perception seizes on the dint in the apple, the crease in the child's shoe, the little notes of expression in the objects which break uniformity and make for art.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378704302470 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA314"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.349.1.0.box.179.211.1009.1682.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA314.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
The Piano and Singing.—I must close, with the disappointing sense that subjects of importance in the child's education have been left out of count, and that no one matter has been adequately treated.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA314.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Certain subjects of peculiar educational value, music, for instance, I have said nothing about, partly for want of space, and partly because if the mother have not Sir Joshua Reynolds's '<span style="font-style:italic;">that</span><span style="font-style:italic;">!' </span>in her, hints from an outsider will not produce the art-feeling which is the condition of success in this sort of teaching. If possible, let the children learn from the first under <span style="font-style:italic;">artists, </span>lovers of their work: it is a serious mistake to let the child lay the foundation of whatever he may do in the future under ill-qualified mechanical teachers, who kindle in him none of the enthusiasm which is the life of art. I should like, in connection with singing, to mention the admirable educational effects of the Tonic Sol-fa method.^1^ ^1^ See Appendix A.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378706259901 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA315"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.350.1.0.box.45.194.1007.1632.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA315.w.1.0.0"></span></a>
Children learn by it in a magical way to produce sign for sound and sound for sign, that is, they can not only read music, but can write the notes for, or make the proper hand signs for, the notes of a passage sung to them. Ear and voice are simultaneously and equally cultivated.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA315.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
Mrs Curwen's <span style="font-style:italic;">Child </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Pianist'^1^ </span>method is worked out, with minute care, upon the same lines; that is, the child's knowledge of the theory of music and his ear training keep pace with his power of execution, and seem to do away with the deadly dreariness of 'practising.'

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA315.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Handicrafts and Drills. — It is not possible to do more than mention two more important subjects—the Handicrafts and Drills—which should form a regular part of a child's daily life. For physical training nothing is so good as Ling's Swedish Drill, and a few of the early exercises are within the reach of children under nine. Dancing, and the various musical drills, lend themselves to grace of movement, and give more pleasure, if less scientific training, to the little people.

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA315.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
The Handicrafts best fitted for children under nine seem to me to be chair-caning, carton-work, basket-work, Smyrna rugs, Japanese curtains, carving in cork, samplers on coarse canvas showing a variety of stitches, easy needlework, knitting (big needles and wool), etc. The points to be borne in mind in children's handicrafts are: <span style="font-style:italic;">(a) </span>that they should not be employed in making futilities such as pea and stick work, paper mats, and the like; <span style="font-style:italic;">(b) </span>that they should be taught slowly and carefully what they are to do; <span style="font-style:italic;">(c) </span>that slipshod work should<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA316.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0079.xml#para.351.1.0.box.180.223.1001.93.q.70" class="gtxt_body"> not be allowed; <span style="font-style:italic;">(d) </span>and that, therefore, the children's work should be kept well within their compass.</span>

</div>

<div id="content-0079.xml#block.350.2.0.box.417.1846.256.32.q.60" class="gtxt_footnote">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA315.w.2.0.0"></span></a>
^1^ See Appendix A.

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378707327051 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA316"></span></a>
<div id="content-0079.xml#block.351.1.0.box.180.223.1007.440.q.70" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0079.xml#GBS.PA316.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
May I hope, in concluding this short review of the subjects proper for a child's intellectual education, that enough has been said to show the necessity of grave consideration on the mother's part before she allows promiscuous little lesson-books to be put into the hands of her children, or trusts ill-qualified persons to strike out methods of teaching for themselves?

</div>

</div>

<span id="content-0080.xml"></span>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378708802407 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA317"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.352.0.0.box.46.560.1005.1344.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA317.w.0.0.0"></span></a>
PART VI

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA317.w.0.1.0"></span></a>
THE WILL—THE CONSCIENCE—THE DIVINE LIFE IN THE CHILD

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA317.w.0.2.0"></span></a>
I.—THE WILL

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA317.w.0.3.0"></span></a>
Government of Mansoul.—We have now to consider a subject of unspeakable importance to every being called upon to sustain a reasonable life here, with the hope of the fuller life hereafter; I mean, the government of the kingdom of Mansoul. Every child who lives long enough in the world is invested, by degrees, with this high function, and it is the part of his parents to instruct him in his duties, and to practise him in his tasks. Now, the government of this kingdom of Mansoul is, like that of some well-ordered states, carried on in three chambers, each chamber with its own functions, exercised, not by a multitude of counsellors, but by a single minister.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA317.w.0.4.0"></span></a>
Executive Power vested in the Will.—In the outer of the three chambers sits the Will. Like that Roman centurion, he has soldiers under him: he says to this man, Go, and he goeth; to another, Come, and he cometh; to a third, Do this, and he doeth it. In other words, the <span style="font-style:italic;">executive </span>power is vested in the will. If the will have the habit of<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA318.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.353.1.0.box.172.226.1001.231.q.50" class="gtxt_body"> authority, if it deliver its mandates in the tone that constrains obedience, the kingdom is, at any rate, at unity with itself. If the will be feeble, of uncertain counsels, poor Mansoul is torn with disorder and rebellion.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378710524885 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA318"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.353.1.0.box.171.226.1007.1676.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA318.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
What is the Will?—I do not know what the will is; it would appear to be an ultimate fact, not admitting of definition: but there are few subjects on which those who have the education of children in their hands make more injurious mistakes; and therefore it is worth while to consider, as we may, what are the functions of the will, and what are its limitations.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA318.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Persons may go through life without deliberate act of Will.—In the first place, the will does not necessarily come into play in any of the aspects in which we have hitherto considered the child. He may reflect and imagine; be stirred by the desire of knowledge, of power, of distinction; may love and esteem; may form habits of attention, obedience, diligence, sloth, <span style="font-style:italic;">i?woluntarily</span>—-that is, without ever intending, purposing, <span style="font-style:italic;">willing </span>these things for himself. So far is this true, that there are people who live through their lives without an act of deliberate will: amiable, easy-going people, on the one hand, hedged in by favouring circumstances; and poor souls, on the other, whom circumstances have <span style="font-style:italic;">not </span>saved, who have drifted from their moorings, and are hardly to be named by those to whom they belong. Great intellectual powers by no means imply a controlling will. We read how Coleridge had to be taken care of, because he had so little power of willing. His thoughts were as little under his own volition as his actions, and the fine talk people went to hear was no<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA319.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.354.1.0.box.46.194.1001.191.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> more than an endless pouring forth of ideas connected by no other link than that of association; though so fine was his mind, that his ideas flowed methodically —of their own accord, so to speak.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378712137205 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA319"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.354.1.0.box.46.194.1008.1681.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA319.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
Character the Result of Conduct regulated by Will.—It is not necessary to say a word about the dignity and force of character which a confirmed will gives to its possessors. In fact, <span style="font-style:italic;">character </span>is the result of conduct regulated by will. We say, So-and-so has a great deal of character, such another is without character; and we might express the fact equally by saying, So-and-so has a vigorous will, such another has no force of will. We all know of lives, rich in gifts and graces, which have been wrecked for the lack of a determining will.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA319.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Three Functions of the Will.—The will is the controller of the passions and emotions, the director of the desires, the ruler of the appetites. But observe, the passions, the desires, the appetites, are there already, and the will gathers force and vigour only as it is exercised in the repression and direction of these; for though the will appears to be of purely spiritual nature, yet it behaves like any member of the body in this—that it becomes vigorous and capable in proportion as it is duly nourished and fitly employed.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA319.w.1.3.0"></span></a>
A Limitation of the Will disregarded by some Novelists.—The villain of a novel, it is true, is, or rather used to be, an interesting person, because he was always endowed with a powerful will, which acted, not in controlling his violent passions, but in aiding and abetting them: the result was a diabolical being out of the common way of nature. And no wonder, for, according to natural law, the member<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA320.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.355.1.0.box.188.220.1001.437.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> which does not fulfil its own functions is punished by loss of power; if it does not cease to be, it becomes as though it were not; and the will, being placed in the seat of authority, is not able to carry its forces over to the mob—the disorder would be too fearful; just as when the executive powers of a state are seized upon by a riotous mob, and there are shootings in the highways and hangings from the lanterns, infinite confusion everywhere.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378714042779 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA320"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.355.1.0.box.188.220.1012.1662.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA320.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
Parents fall into this Metaphysical Blunder.— I am anxious to bring before you this limitation of the will to its own proper functions, because parents often enough fall into the very metaphysical blunder we have seen in the novel-writer. They admire a vigorous will, and rightly. They know that if their child is to make his mark in the world, it must be by force of will. What follows? The baby screams himself into fits for a forbidden plaything, and the mother says, ' He has such a strong will.' The little fellow of three stands roaring in the street, and will neither go hither nor thither with his nurse, because 'he has such a strong will.' He <span style="font-style:italic;">will </span>rule the sports of the nursery, <span style="font-style:italic;">will </span>monopolise his sisters' playthings, all because of this 'strong will.' Now we come to a divergence of opinion: on the one hand, the parents decide that, whatever the consequence, the child's will is not to be broken, so all his vagaries must go unchecked; on the other, the decision is, that the child's will must be broken at all hazards, and the poor little being is subjected to a dreary round of punishment and repression.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA320.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Wilfulness indicates want of Will Power.— But, all the time, nobody perceives that it is the mere want of will that is the matter with the child. He is<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA321.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.356.1.0.box.36.194.1003.630.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> in a state of absolute 'wilfulness,'—the rather unfortunate word we use to describe the state in which the will has no controlling power; <span style="font-style:italic;">willessness, </span>if there were such a word, would describe this state more truly. Now, this confusion, in the minds of many persons, between the state of wilfulness and that of being dominated by will, leads to mischievous results even where wilfulness is not fostered nor the child unduly repressed: it leads to the neglect of the due cultivation and training of the will, that almost divine possession, upon the employment of which every other gift, be it beauty or genius, strength or skill, depends for its value.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378716016004 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA321"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.356.1.0.box.36.194.1003.1672.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA321.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
What is Wilfulness ?—What, then, is wilfulness, if it be not an exercise of will? Simply this: remove bit and bridle—that is, the control of the will—from the appetites, the desires, the emotions, and the child who has mounted his hobby, be it resentment, jealousy, desire of power, desire of property, is another Mazeppa, borne along with the speed of the swift and the strength of the strong, and with no power at all to help himself. Appetite, passion, there is no limit to their power and their persistence if the appointed check be removed; and it is this impetus of appetite or of passion, this apparent determination to go in one way and no other, which is called wilfulness and mistaken for an exercise of will. Whereas the <span style="font-style:italic;">determination </span>is only apparent; the child is, in fact, hurried along without resistance, because that opposing force which should give balance to his character is undeveloped and untrained.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA321.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
The Will has Superior and Inferior Functions.—The will has its superior and its inferior, what may be called its moral and its mechanical,<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA322.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.357.1.0.box.226.219.1003.240.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> functions; and that will which, for want of practice, has grown flaccid and feeble in the exercise of its higher functions, may yet be able for the ordering of such matters as going or coming, sitting or standing, speaking or refraining from speech.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378717988645 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA322"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.357.1.0.box.226.219.1003.1667.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA322.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
The Will not a Moral Faculty.—Again, though it is impossible to attain moral excellence of character without the agency of a vigorous will, the will itself is not a moral faculty, and a man may attain great strength of will in consequence of continued efforts in the repression or direction of his appetites or desires, and yet be an unworthy man; that is, he may be keeping himself in order from unworthy motives, for the sake of appearances, for his own interest, even for the injury of another.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA322.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
A Disciplined Will necessary to Heroic Christian Character.—Once again, though a disciplined will is not a necessary condition of the Christian life, it <span style="font-style:italic;">is </span>necessary to the development of the heroic Christian character. A Gordon, a Havelock, a Florence Nightingale, a St Paul, could not be other than a person of vigorous will. In this respect, as in all others, Christianity reaches the feeblest souls. There is a wonderful Guido 'Magdalen' in the Louvre, with a mouth which has plainly never been set to any resolve for good or ill—a lower face moulded by the helpless following of the inclination of the moment; but you look up to the eyes, which are raised to meet the gaze of eyes not shown in the picture, and the countenance is transfigured, the whole face is aglow with a passion of service, love, and self-surrender. All this the divine grace may accomplish in weak ?\*\#willing souls, and then they will do what they can; but their power of service is<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA323.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.358.1.0.box.45.193.1004.389.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> limited by their past. Not so the child of the Christian mother, whose highest desire is to train him for the Christian life. When he wakes to the consciousness of whose he is and whom he serves, she would have him ready for that high service, with every faculty in training—a man of war from his youth; above all, with an effective will, to will and to do of His good pleasure.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378719994263 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA323"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.358.1.0.box.45.193.1005.1675.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA323.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
The sole Practical Faculty of Man.—Before we consider how to train this 'sole practical faculty of man,' we must know how the will operates—how it manages the ordering of all that is done and thought in the kingdom of Mansoul. "Can't you make yourself do what you wish to do?" says Guy, in the <span style="font-style:italic;">Heir </span><span style="font-style:italic;">of </span><span style="font-style:italic;">Redclyffe, </span>to poor Charlie Edmonston, who has never been in the habit of <span style="font-style:italic;">making </span>himself do anything. There are those, no doubt, who have not even arrived at wishing, but most of us desire to do well; what we want to know is, how to <span style="font-style:italic;">make </span>ourselves do what we desire. And here is the line which divides the effective from the non-effective people, the great from the small, the good from the well-intentioned and respectable; it is in proportion as a man has self-controlling, self-compelling power that he is able to do, even of his own pleasure; that he can depend upon himself, and be sure of his own action in emergencies.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA323.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
How the Will operates.—Now, how does this autocrat of the bosom behave? Is it with a stern 'Thou shalt,'' Thou shalt not,' that the subject man is coerced into obedience? By no means. Is it by a plausible show of reasons, mustering of motives? Not this either. Since Mr John Stuart Mill taught us that " all that man does, or can do, with matter"<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA324.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.359.1.0.box.203.195.1007.1122.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> is to " move one thing to or from another," we need not be surprised if great moral results are brought about by what seem inadequate means; and a little bit of nursery experience will show better than much talking what is possible to the will. A baby falls, gets a bad bump, and cries piteously. The experienced nurse does not " kiss the place to make it well," or show any pity for the child's trouble—that would make matters worse; the more she pities, the more he sobs. She hastens to 'change his thoughts,' so she says; she carries him to the window to see the horses, gives him his pet picture-book, his dearest toy, and the child pulls himself up in the middle of a sob, though he is really badly hurt. Now this, of the knowing nurse, is precisely the part the will plays towards the man. It is by force of will that a man can 'change his thoughts,' transfer his attention from one subject of thought to another, and that, with a shock of mental force of which he is distinctly conscious. And this is enough to save a man and to make a man, this power of making himself think only of those things which he has beforehand decided that it is good to think upon.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378721998209 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA324"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.359.1.0.box.203.195.1011.1667.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA324.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
The Way of the Will—Incentives.—His thoughts are wandering on forbidden pleasures, to the hindrance of his work; he pulls himself up, and deliberately fixes his attention on those incentives which have most power to make him work, the leisure and pleasure which follow honest labour, the duty which binds him to the fulfilling of his task. His thoughts run in the groove he <span style="font-style:italic;">wills </span>them to run in, and work is no longer an effort.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA324.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Diversion.—Again, some slight affront has called up a flood of resentful feeling: So-and-so should not<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA325.w.0.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.360.0.0.box.169.178.880.35.q.70" class="gtxt_body"> THE WILL—CONSCIENCE—DIVINE LIFE 325</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378724471472 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA325"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.360.0.0.box.45.178.1011.1755.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA325.w.0.1.0"></span></a>
have done it, he had no <span style="font-style:italic;">right, </span>it was mean, and so on, through all the hard things we are ready enough to say in our hearts of an offender against our <span style="font-style:italic;">amour </span><span style="font-style:italic;">prof </span><span style="font-style:italic;">re. </span>But the man under the control of his own will does not allow this to go on: he does not fight it out with himself, and say,' This is very wrong in me. So-and-so is not so much to blame, after all. He is not ready for that yet; but he just compels himself to think of something else—the last book he has read, the next letter he must write, anything interesting enough to divert his thoughts. When he allows himself to go back to the cause of offence, behold, all rancour is gone, and he is able to look at the matter with the coolness of a third person. And this is true, not only of the risings of resentment, but of every temptation that besets the flesh and spirit.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA325.w.0.2.0"></span></a>
Change of Thought.—Again, the sameness of his duties, the weariness of doing the same thing over and over, fills him with disgust and despondency, and he relaxes his efforts ;—but not if he be a man under the power of his own will, because he simply does not allow himself in idle discontent; it is always within his power to give himself something pleasant, something outside of himself, to think of, and he does so; and, given what we call a ' happy frame of mind,' no work is laborious.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA325.w.0.3.0"></span></a>
The Way of the Will should be taught to Children.—It is something to <span style="font-style:italic;">know </span>what to do with ourselves when we are beset, and the knowledge of this <span style="font-style:italic;">way </span><span style="font-style:italic;">of </span><span style="font-style:italic;">the </span><span style="font-style:italic;">tvill </span>is so far the secret of a happy life, that it is well worth imparting to the children. Are you cross? Change your thoughts. Are you tired of trying? Change your thoughts. Are you craving for things you are not to have? Change your thoughts;<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA326.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.361.1.0.box.193.270.1002.430.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> there is a power within you, your own will, which will enable you to turn your attention from thoughts that make you unhappy <span style="font-style:italic;">and </span><span style="font-style:italic;">wrong, </span>to thoughts that make you happy <span style="font-style:italic;">and </span><span style="font-style:italic;">right. </span>And this is the exceedingly simple way in which the will acts; this is the sole secret of the power over himself which the strong man wields—he can compel himself to think of what he chooses, and <span style="font-style:italic;">will </span>not allow himself in thoughts that breed mischief.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378726541544 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA326"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.361.1.0.box.193.270.1009.1672.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA326.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
Power of Will implies Power of Attention.— But you perceive that, though the will is all-powerful within certain limits, these are but narrow limits after all. Much must go before and along with a vigorous will if it is to be a power in the ruling of conduct. For instance, the man must have acquired the habit of <span style="font-style:italic;">attention, </span>the great importance of which we have already considered. There are bird-witted people, who have no power of thinking connectedly for five minutes under any pressure, from within or from without. If they have never been trained to apply the whole of their mental faculties to a given subject, why, no energy of will, supposing they had it, which is impossible, could make them think steadily thoughts of their own choosing or of anyone else's. Here is how the parts of the intellectual fabric dovetail: power of will implies power of attention; and before the parent can begin to train the will of the child, he must have begun to form in him the habit of attention.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA326.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
Habit may Frustrate the Will.—Again, we have already considered the fatal facility in evil, the impulse towards good, which <span style="font-style:italic;">habit </span>gives. Habit is either the ally or the opponent, too often the frustrator, of the will. The unhappy drunkard does <span style="font-style:italic;">will </span>with what strength there is in him; he turns away the eyes of<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA327.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.362.1.0.box.47.194.1001.631.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> his mind from beholding his snare; he plies himself assiduously with other thoughts; but alas, his thoughts will only run in the accustomed groove of desire, and <span style="font-style:italic;">habit </span>is too strong for his feeble will. We all know something of this struggle between habit and will in less vital matters. Who is without some dilatory, procrastinating, in some way tiresome, habit, which is in almost daily struggle with the rectified will? But I have already said so much about the duty of parents to ease the way of their children by laying down for them the lines of helpful habits, that it is unnecessary to say a word more here of habit as an ally or a hinderer of the will.</span>

</div>

</div>

<!-- Content from Google Book Search, generated at 1430378728744615 -->
<div class="flow" style="">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA327"></span></a>
<div id="content-0080.xml#block.362.1.0.box.45.194.1003.1680.q.60" class="gtxt_body">

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA327.w.1.1.0"></span></a>
Reasonable Use of so effective an Instrument.—And, once more, only the man of cultivated reason is capable of being ruled by a well-directed will. If his understanding does not show good <span style="font-style:italic;">cause </span><span style="font-style:italic;">why </span>he should do some solid reading every day, <span style="font-style:italic;">why </span>he should cling to the faith of his fathers, <span style="font-style:italic;">why </span>he should take up his duties as a citizen,—the movement of his will will be feeble and fluctuating, and very barren of results. And, indeed, worse may happen: he may take up some wrong-headed, or even vicious, notion and work a great deal of mischief by what he feels to be a virtuous effort of will. The parent may venture to place the power of will in the hands of his child only in so far as he trains him to make a reasonable use of so effective an instrument.

<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA327.w.1.2.0"></span></a>
How to Strengthen the Will.—One other limitation of the will we shall consider presently; but supposing the parent take pains that the child shall be in a fit state to use his will, how is he to strengthen that will, so that by and by the child may employ it to control his own life by? We have spoken already<span id="content-0080.xml#GBS.PA328.w.1.0.0"></span></a><span id="content-0080.xml#para.363.1.0.box.174.189.1005.979.q.60" class="gtxt_body"> of the importance of training the child in the habit of obedience. Now, obedience is valuable only in so far as it helps the child towards making himself do that which he knows he ought to do. Every effort of obedience which does not give him a sense <span style="font-style:italic;">of </span><span style="font-style:italic;">conquest </span>over his own inclinations, helps to enslave him, and he will resent the loss of his liberty by running into license when he can. That is the secret of the miscarrying of many strictly brought-up children.
